lines.text: Ebenezer? Remember when I was alive I robbed from widows and swindled the poor?
Yes, and all in the same day. Oh, you had class, Jacob.
Ha-yuk. Yup. Er, no, no! I was wrong. And so, as punishment, I'm forced to carry these heavy chains for eternity! Maybe even longer.

My partner, Jacob Marley, dead seven years today. Oh, he was a good'n. He robbed from the widows and swindled the poor. In his will, he left me enough money to pay for his tombstone, and I have him burried at sea!
Well, it's about time! Haven't got all night, you know.
Who... who are you?
Why, I'm the Ghost of Christmas Past.
Oh. I thought you'd be taller.
Hmph! Listen, Scrooge, if men were measured by kindness, you'd be no bigger than a speck of dust.

[yawns]
Kindness is of little use in this world.
You didn't always think so. Come on, Scrooge, it's time to go.
Then go!
And what can I do for you two gentlemen?
Sir, we are collecting funds for the indigent and destitute.
For the what?

[tipping his hat]
We're collecting for the poor.
Oh. Aha. Well um, you realize if you give money to the poor, they won't be poor anymore, will they?
Well, I...
And if they're not *poor* anymore, then you won't have to raise money for them anymore.
Well, I suppose...
And if you don't have to raise money for them anymore, then you'd be out of a job. Oh please, gentlemen, don't ask me to put you out of a job. Not on Christmas Eve.
Oh, we wouldn't do that, Mr. Scrooge.

[giving them a wreath]
Well then, I suggest you give this to the poor and be gone.
[Slams door on them]
What's this world coming to, Cratchit? You work all your life to get money... then people want you to give it away.
Merry Christmas, Uncle Scrooge!
What's so merry about it? I'll tell you what Christmas is. It's just another work day, and any jackanape who thinks else should be boiled in his own pudding!
But sir, Christmas is a time for giving... a time to be with one's family.
I say, Bah humbug!
I don't care! I say, Merry Christmas. Merry Christmas!

[clapping]
Well said, Master Fred!
Cratchit, what are you doing?

[stops clapping]
I was just trying to keep my hands warm, sir.
Ah, I remember how much I was in love with her.
[a wind blows and the lights inside go out]
In ten years time, you learned to love something else.
Why, it's my counting house.
[Scrooge sees himself sitting in his chair counting money]
Ebenezer?
Yes, what is it?
For years, I've had this honeymoon cottage, Ebenezer. I've been waiting for you to keep your promise to marry me. Now I must know, have you made your decision?
I have! Your last payment on the cottage was an hour late! I'm foreclosing the mortgage!
[Belle walks away, crying]
You loved your gold more than that precious creature, and you lost her forever.
[Belle leaves and slams the door behind her, hard enough to make the coins clatter everywhere]
Please, spirit, I can no longer bear these memories! Take me home!
Remember, Scrooge, you fashioned these memories yourself.
Tell me, spirit, what's wrong with that tiny lad?
Much, I'm afraid. If these shadows remain unchanged, I see an empty chair where Tiny Tim once sat.
Then that means Tim will...
Spirit, whose lonely grave - is this?
it reads "EBENEZER SCROOGE"]

[Pulls back his hood, revealing himself to the viewers as Pete, then tossing Scrooge into the grave]
Why, yours, Ebenezer! The richest man in the cemetery! HAHAHAHAHAHA!
Tomorrow is Christmas and I was wondering if I could have... Half a day off?
Christmas, eh? Uh, er... I suppose so. But I'll dock you half a day's pay. Let's see, I pay you two shillings a day...
Two shillings and a halfpenny, Sir.
Oh yes, I gave you that raise three years ago.
Yes, sir, when I started doing your laundry.
I've come to give you a wreath and invite you to Christmas dinner.
Well, I suppose you're going to have plump goose with chesnut dressing?
Yup.
And will you have plum pudding and lemon sauce?
Yeah, boy oh boy.
And candied fruit with spiced sugar cakes?
Yeah. Will you come?
Are you daft, man? You know I can't eat that stuff! Here's your wreath back. Now, out, out, OUT!
[kicks Fred out the door and slams it after him]
00. Scrooge looks at his watch]
Hmm... Two minutes fast.
[Bob stops then goes back to his desk]
Well, never mind those two minutes. You may go now.
Ah, oh thank you, sir! You're so kind!
Never mind that mushy stuff, just go! But be here all the other early the next day!
I will, I will, sir! And a Bah Humbug... I mean, a Merry Christmas to you, sir!
Tonight, you will be visited by three spirits.
[holds up two fingers]
Listen to 'em. Do what they say, or your chains will be heavier than mine. Farewell, Ebenezer.
[gliding through door]
Fareweeeellll...
Marley, watch out for that first...
[Marley goes crashing down the stairs]
Step.
Merry Christmas, Bob.
And God bless us, everyone.
Oh, that Fred. Always so full of kindness.
Aye. He always was a little peculiar
[door bell rings]
... AND stubborn!

[as Scrooge panics while flying toward the past]
What's wrong, Scrooge?
[laughs]
I thought you enjoyed looking down on the world!
Ebeneezer?
Yes, Isabelle?
My eyes are closed, my lips are puckered, and I'm standing under the mistletoe.
You're also standing on my foot.
Please, let me go! Don't eat me!
Why would the Ghost of Christmas Present - that's me - want to eat a distasteful little miser like you?... Especially when there are so many good things to enjoy in life?
Where did all this come from?
From the heart, Scrooge. It's the food of generosity, which you have long denied your fellow man.
Generosity? Ha! Nobody has ever shown me generosity!
You've never given them a reason to.
[plucks off a grape then gulps it]
And yet... there are some who still find enough warmth in their hearts even for the likes of you.
Hmph! No acquaintence of mine, I assure you.
Duh, you'll see.
Oh my! Look at all the wonderful things to eat! We must thank Mister Scrooge.
Why, Mr. Scrooge, Merry Christmas.
[Scrooge barges in]
Won't you come in?
Merry Christmas? Humph! I have another bundle for you.
But sir, it's Christmas Day.
I've had enough of this 'half-day off' stuff! You leave me no alternative...
[changing his attitude]
...but to give you...

[sees the contents of the now open bag]
Toys!
Yes, toys. No no no no no no no!
[lovingly]
I'm giving you a raise... and making you my partner.
What's she cooking, a canary? Surely they have more food than that. Look on the fire.
Huh, where? Oh, that's your laundry.
An-and that shy lad in the corner, that's me.
Yes, that was before you became a miserable miser, consumed by greed.
Well, nobody's perfect. And there-there's lovely Isabelle.
Oh, it's a wonderful day.
[laughs]
So much to do. So much to do...

[leaves, comes back upstairs, realizing he's only wearing his nightshirt]
I can't go out like this.

[takes a cane]
There, that's better.
Ah, nephew!
Uncle Scrooge!
I'm looking forward to that wonderful meal of yours.
Well, I'll be doggone. You mean you're coming?
Of course I am! You know how much I love candied fruit and sweet sugar cakes.
[Fred laughs]
I'll be there promptly at two! Keep it piping hot!
I will, Uncle Scrooge, I will! And a very merry Christmas to you!
Don't forget the chocolate pot roast with smishmashio... With smiminish... With yogurt.
I'll change! I'LL CHANGE!
Bah humbug!
Spirit, I didn't want this to happen. Tell me these events can yet be changed.
I've never seen a funeral like this one.
Aye. No mourners, no friends to bid him farewell.
Oh, well. Let's rest a minute before we throw 'im in, eh? He ain't going nowhere.
[both laugh as they leave]
Merry Christmas to one and all!
[Slides down banister]
Ah, bless me. Good morning, gentlemen. I've something for ya.
[Puts a bag of coins on the second collector's head]
Twenty gold sovereigns! Oh, no!
Not enough? Here.
[Puts another bag on the collector's pants]
Fifty gold sovereigns!
Really, Mister Scrooge. It's...
Still not enough! You drive a hard bargain. Here you are.
[Throws several bags at the collectors]
One hundred gold pieces, and not a penny more!
Oh, thank you, Mr. Scrooge! Thank you! And a *merry* Christmas to you!
Ha-ha. That Fred, always so full of kindness.
Aye, he always was a little peculiar
[the doorbell rings again]
AND stubborn!

[Scrooge is being windblown into his past]
AHHH!
What's the matter, Scrooge? I thought you enjoyed looking down on the world.
Spirit, whose lone grave is this?
[Ghost flicks a lighter revealing Scrooge's name on the tombstone, gasps, Ghost removes his hood and lights a cigar]
Why yours, Ebenezer. The richest man in the cemetery!
[laughs as he throws Scrooge in the grave]
IT'S CHRISTMAS MORNING! I haven't missed it! The spirits have given me another chance!
